content:
Project: Natural Language Processing for Stock Market Indicator

Section: Overview


**Objective:** Develop a reliable stock market indicator based on Twitter sentiment for stocks like AAPL, AMZN, GOOG, MSFT, and TSLA.

![Image: photo_2024-08-27 17.24.41.jpeg]

**Approach:**

- **Data Collection:** Assembled a multivariable dataset combining historical stock market data with aggregated Twitter sentiment with pandas library.
 
 ![Image: Screenshot 2024-08-27 at 5.26.55 PM.png]
 
 ![Image: Screenshot 2024-08-27 at 5.31.15 PM.png]
 
- **Financial Sentiment Analysis:** Utilised the Hugging Face FinBERT model to analyse daily sentiment of tweets. Calculated a weighted average sentiment score, factoring in likes, retweets, and comments.
- **Modelling:** Explored the Random Forest Classifier, performing 5-fold cross-validation and Grid Search CV to optimised parameters.
 
 ![Image: Screenshot 2024-08-27 at 5.35.12 PM.png]

**Outcome:**

- Achieved 85.2% accuracy in predicting daily stock market indicators.
 
 ![Image: Screenshot 2024-08-27 at 5.33.52 PM.png]
 
- Demonstrated that Twitter sentiment significantly influences market movements.
 
 ![Image: Screenshot 2024-08-27 at 5.33.21 PM.png]

content:
Project: Deep Learning for Skin Lesion Classification

Section: **Deep Learning for Skin Cancer Detection**


**Objective:** Develop an AI model capable of detecting skin cancer with accuracy comparable to a doctor's expertise.

**Challenge:** With 99% of skin cancer cases being preventable if detected early, the goal was to create an automated and reliable system to identify the presence or absence of skin cancer in individuals using limited information.

**Outcome:** The project focused on leveraging advanced AI and deep learning techniques to ensure accurate and early detection, potentially reducing the incidence of skin cancer through timely intervention.

content:
Project: Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board Manpower Optimisation System

Section: **Manpower Optimisation System for CPF**


**Objective:** Develop a system to optimise manpower allocation for the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board, addressing the challenge of accurately forecasting enquiry volumes during peak periods.

**Challenge:** CPF faced operational inefficiencies due to inaccurate forecasting of incoming enquiry volumes, leading to over/understaffing and unnecessary operational costs.

**Approach:**

- **Stakeholder Engagement:** Conducted site visits and interviews with key stakeholders to understand pain points.
- **Design Prototyping:** Iterated multiple design prototypes with the client, refining the solution to meet their needs.
- **Manpower Optimisation:** Designed a system to address forecasting challenges and optimise staff allocation.

**Role:**

- Led the design of solutions for each identified pain point, creating Figma prototypes.
- Developed a mathematical model to effectively forecast enquiry demand.
- Researched and selected a suitable simulation system to support the project’s objectives.

content:
Project: Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board Manpower Optimisation System

Section: Simulating Open Balance


---

- **Forecasting New Incoming Cases** - With historical data of daily new cases, our machine learning regression model is able to forecast the number of new cases coming in.
 
 ![Screenshot 2024-08-28 at 2.23.49 PM.png](Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board Manpower Optimi b2d449e2d8584adbaf3efcfdcede232c/Screenshot_2024-08-28_at_2.23.49_PM.png)
 
- **Simulating Total Closed Case** - With historical data of daily productivity rate for each employee type, we are able to make an accurate prediction of number of daily case closure rate.
 
 ![Screenshot 2024-08-28 at 2.27.12 PM.png](Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board Manpower Optimi b2d449e2d8584adbaf3efcfdcede232c/Screenshot_2024-08-28_at_2.27.12_PM.png)
 
- **Simulating Open Balance** - With the above 2 data, we simply simulate open balance of cases for the upcoming week by finding the difference between both!
 
 ![Screenshot 2024-08-28 at 2.28.32 PM.png](Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board Manpower Optimi b2d449e2d8584adbaf3efcfdcede232c/Screenshot_2024-08-28_at_2.28.32_PM.png)

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_ReImagine Public Engagement (URA) 19bf57abcb4e80e9a12bf72588a5f7fb_section_1
content:
Project: ReImagine Public Engagement (URA)

Section: Overview


---

![dfe9a804-9375-4661-935a-bf3eb74e9956.JPG](ReImagine Public Engagement (URA) 19bf57abcb4e80e9a12bf72588a5f7fb/dfe9a804-9375-4661-935a-bf3eb74e9956.jpg)

To enhance urban planing through inclusive public engagement, I contributed to an **AI-driven application** designed for the **Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA)**. This application streamlines engagement sessions by leveraging **generative AI** technologies to visualise **public feedback** as **actionable design insights**.

- AI-Powered Engagement: Integrated **Generative AI tools** (image inpainting, prompt upscaling, AI critique) to enhance public engagement quality.
- Interactive Public Engagement Platform: Developed a **user-friendly web application** that allows participants to visually express their ideas, submit feedback, engage with AI-generated urban design proposals in real time.
- Admin-Facing Platform: Designed and implemented an **admin dashboard** using **Figma for prototyping** and **React for front-end development**, streamlining the management of public input.
- User Testing & Evaluation: Conducted real-world trials comparing **traditional and AI-enhanced engagement methods**, demonstrating improved participant **satisfaction, engagement, and usability**.

content:
Project: ReImagine Public Engagement (URA)

Section: **1. AI-Driven Public Engagement Platform**


- A web-based application designed to facilitate **seamless public participation**, allowing users to provide input on urban spaces through **text-based and visual interactions**.
- Uses **Generative AI** (image inpainting, prompt upscaling, and AI critique) to **translate user ideas into visualised design concepts**, helping participants see the potential impact of their suggestions.
- Users can **view and upvote** other participants' urban design ideas, fostering a **collaborative** highlighting the most popular community-driven solutions.

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_The Guiding Hand 2d1bc872300e4a248f1b3a8ef4d2384d_section_1
content:
Project: The Guiding Hand

Section: **Overview**


![Image: Screenshot 2023-08-13 225841.png]

---

**Addressing High Abortion Rates and Declining Birth Rates in Singapore**

**Objective:** Collaborate with Gebirah, a non-profit organisation, to tackle pressing issues related to high abortion rates, unsafe practices, and declining birth rates in Singapore. In 2020, there were 4,029 recorded abortions, averaging 336 per month, some involving underage girls. These challenges exacerbate the nation's aging population and endanger maternal and fetal health.

**Key Challenges:**

- **Access to Support:** How can we make it easier for women facing unplanned pregnancies to access personalised assistance, connect with professional counselors, and receive necessary emotional support without overwhelming or complicating the process?
- **Streamlining Services:** How can we streamline the handling of inquiries and prioritize cases effectively without compromising service quality or burdening administrators with complex features?

**Our Role:** With a team of six, we aimed to unify information from independent help centers and the government, providing a comprehensive support system for those in need. Our focus was on simplifying access to resources, improving case management, and ensuring the delivery of compassionate, effective care.

content:
Project: Re-thinking the EVAM rocker.

Section: Overview


![Image: Screenshot 2023-04-05 at 12.26.23 AM.png]

---

**Optimising Rocker Design for Material and Energy Savings through Additive Manufacturing**

- Our task was to optimise the rocker component to reduce mass and energy usage.

**Approach:**

- **Physics Analysis:** We first studied the physics of the original rocker to understand its load-bearing requirements.
- **Generative Design:** Used Fusion 360’s generative design tools to create innovative rocker designs that meet the required loads and constraints.
- **Material Analysis:** Conducted material analysis to identify the best options for maximising energy and mass savings.
- **Life Cycle Analysis:** Compared the new and original designs, resulting in a 72% reduction in CO2 emissions.

content:
Project: Designing the EVAM’s interior

Section: **Interior Design for SUTD's EVAM (Electric Vehicle Additive Manufactured)**


**Objective:** Design the interior of EVAM, SUTD’s F1-themed electric vehicle, which arrived as a skeleton with no interior design. The goal was to address client concerns and reflect SUTD’s identity.

**Approach:**

- **Client Requirements:** Focused on issues such as ease of entry and exit, designing features like armrests and side compartments for both front and rear seats, and a leg and heel rest for the driver. These features included step platforms and handles to facilitate access for elderly passengers and children.
- **Design Development:** Over 14 weeks, our team produced a vision render for the EVAM’s interior and developed physical prototypes of the steering wheel, dashboard UI, and screens for both driver and passenger.

**My Deliverables**:

- **Design Solutions:** Addressed key issues by designing practical components to improve vehicle accessibility and comfort.
- **Prototyping:** Developed physical prototypes of the steering wheel, and passenger and driver screens.

**Learning Outcomes:**

- Emphasised the importance of storyboarding to effectively communicate ideas.
- Gained experience in hand sketching for initial ideation, producing numerous quick sketches to explore concepts.
- Created a mood board to establish the design tone, feel, and identity, ensuring uniformity across all components.

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5_section_1
content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: Project Overview


---

Sentiment analysis is a crucial Natural Language Processing (NLP) task used in various industries, from customer feedback analysis to financial market predictions. This project explores different deep learning architectures to enhance sentiment classification performance on the **IMDB movie reviews dataset**, a widely used benchmark for binary sentiment analysis (positive vs. negative reviews). Our final model, **LoRA-RoBERTa**, achieved the **highest performance**, with an **F1-score of 0.9407** on the test set, demonstrating its ability to accurately capture nuanced sentiment in text. This project highlights the power of **transformer-based models** and **efficient fine-tuning techniques** in advancing sentiment analysis.

metadata.title: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge - Project Overview

content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: Approach & Methodology


---

To systematically improve sentiment classification performance, we experimented with various deep learning architectures, progressively enhancing model accuracy and interpretability.

metadata.title: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge - Approach & Methodology

source_file: data/raw/notion_export/Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f/Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405/Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5.md

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5_section_3
content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: **Baseline Models: BiRNN & TextCNN**


We started with **BiRNN (Bidirectional Recurrent Neural Network)** and **TextCNN (Text-based Convolutional Neural Network)** as our baseline models.

- **BiRNN** captured sequential dependencies in text but had limitations in handling long-range dependencies.
- **TextCNN**, leveraging convolutional layers, excelled at recognizing local n-gram patterns but lacked sequential understanding.
- Performance Benchmark: **BiRNN achieved 86.48% accuracy, while TextCNN underperformed at 54.94% accuracy**, highlighting the need for further improvements.

metadata.title: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge - **Baseline Models: BiRNN & TextCNN**

source_file: data/raw/notion_export/Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f/Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405/Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5.md

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5_section_4
content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: **Ensemble Model: Attention-Based Aggregation**


To leverage the strengths of both BiRNN and TextCNN, we implemented an **ensemble model** using an **attention-based weighted aggregation mechanism**:

- **Simple Ensemble:** Averaged predictions from BiRNN and TextCNN.
- **Attention-Based Ensemble:** Assigned dynamic weights to each model’s output based on contextual importance.
- **Custom Embeddings:** Replaced standard GloVe embeddings with domain-specific Word2Vec embeddings for richer feature representation.
- **Results:** This approach improved performance, achieving **92.67% accuracy and an F1-score of 0.9273**, but we aimed for further optimization.

metadata.title: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge - **Ensemble Model: Attention-Based Aggregation**

source_file: data/raw/notion_export/Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f/Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405/Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5.md

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5_section_5
content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: **RoBERTa-BiLSTM: Contextual Embeddings + Sequential Understanding**


To incorporate **pre-trained language models**, we introduced **RoBERTa** to generate deep contextual embeddings and **BiLSTM (Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory)** to capture sequential dependencies.

- **RoBERTa provided robust sentence-level representations**, improving sentiment understanding.
- **BiLSTM processed embeddings bidirectionally**, retaining contextual dependencies across longer text spans.
- **Results:** This model further improved accuracy to **93.92% with an F1-score of 0.9393**.

metadata.title: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge - **RoBERTa-BiLSTM: Contextual Embeddings + Sequential Understanding**

source_file: data/raw/notion_export/Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f/Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405/Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5.md

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5_section_6
content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: **LoRA-RoBERTa: Efficient Transformer Fine-Tuning (Final Model)**


Given computational constraints, we fine-tuned **RoBERTa-large** using **Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)**, a parameter-efficient tuning method.

- **Why LoRA?** Instead of updating all 355M parameters in RoBERTa-large, LoRA fine-tuned only a subset of trainable parameters, significantly reducing memory requirements while maintaining high performance.
- **Optimization Techniques:** Used **AdamW optimizer, gradient clipping, and linear learning rate scheduling** for stable training.
- **Final Results:** **LoRA-RoBERTa achieved the best performance with an F1-score of 0.9407**, outperforming all previous models.

metadata.title: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge - **LoRA-RoBERTa: Efficient Transformer Fine-Tuning (Final Model)**

source_file: data/raw/notion_export/Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f/Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405/Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5.md

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5_section_7
content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: Results


---

Through systematic experimentation, we observed consistent improvements in sentiment classification performance as we transitioned from traditional deep learning models to **transformer-based architectures**.

| Model | Accuracy | Precision | Recall | F1 score |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **BiRNN (Baseline)** | 86.48% | 83.85% | 90.34% | 86.97% |
| **TextCNN (Baseline)** | 54.94% | 52.61% | 98.88% | 68.67% |
| **Ensemble Model** | 92.67% | 91.90% | 93.58% | 92.73% |
| **RoBERTa-BiLSTM** | 93.92% | 93.68% | 94.18% | 93.93% |
| **LoRA-RoBERTa** | 94.08% | 94.25% | 93.88% | 94.07% |

📌 **Key Takeaways:**

- **BiRNN performed well but struggled with long-range dependencies.**
- **TextCNN underperformed due to its lack of sequential context.**
- **The Ensemble model improved performance** by combining both architectures with attention-based weighting.
- **RoBERTa-BiLSTM outperformed the ensemble model** by leveraging contextual embeddings with sequential processing.
- **LoRA-RoBERTa achieved the best results, demonstrating the effectiveness of transformer-based fine-tuning.**
source_file: data/raw/notion_export/Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f/Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405/Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5.md

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5_section_8
content:
Project: Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge

Section: Challenges


---

🔹 **Computational Constraints:**

- **Challenge:** Training **RoBERTa-large** was computationally expensive.
- **Solution:** Used **Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)** to fine-tune only a subset of parameters, reducing memory usage while maintaining high performance.

🔹 **Dataset Preprocessing Issues:**

- **Challenge:** The IMDB dataset required extensive text cleaning and handling of imbalanced classes.
- **Solution:** Implemented **NLTK-based preprocessing** (lemmatization, stopword removal) and **balanced batches** using PyTorch DataLoader.

🔹 **Hyperparameter Optimization:**

- **Challenge:** Finding the best learning rate, batch size, and hidden dimensions was time-intensive.
- **Solution:** Used **Grid Search** to optimize hyperparameters efficiently.
source_file: data/raw/notion_export/Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f/Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405/Sentiment Analysis Design Challenge 19bf57abcb4e80df9ea1f974bfd399b5.md

id: Chin Wei Ming’s Portfolio 28d2a0713ab449fa82d8851c163d4b1f_Projects aee4f34d22394d1690473e4917727405_Re-thinking Expo MRT 9a38f07ad6a64023972871810c123c35_section_1
content:
Project: Re-thinking Expo MRT

Section: Overview


![Image: photo_2022-04-22-20.48.06.jpeg]

---

The Expo MRT station, built over 20 years ago, no longer meets the needs of modern commuters, especially during peak hours. Our team reimagined the station's layout from an architectural perspective to enhance movement efficiency. We focused on optimising human traffic flow during peak periods.

I led the 3D modelling process, using Fusion 360 to bring our team's ideas to life. This involved multiple iterations to refine the design and address potential flaws. Once finalised, I developed the physical prototype. While our design may not be implemented, it serves as a valuable reference for future train station designs globally.

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore aims to enhance urban planning

through inclusive public engagement. This project introduces an innovative AI-driven
application to streamline and enrich engagement sessions. The application provides tools for
visualizing public feedback as actionable design inputs, bridging the gap between traditional
manual processes and modern digital frameworks.
The system integrates generative AI technologies for tasks like inpainting, image generation,
prompt upscaling, and topic categorization. It supports both users and administrators by offering
interactive interfaces for inputting ideas, analyzing responses, and visualizing outcomes. Testing
involved real-world participant trials comparing conventional and AI-based workflows,
demonstrating improved satisfaction, engagement, and output quality with the AI approach.

metadata.title: None Report - The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore aims to enhance urban planning
metadata.section_name: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore aims to enhance urban planning

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Key results include:

● Enhanced participant satisfaction and engagement with the AI workflow.
● Simplified and accelerated data processing through integrated AI pipelines.
● Increased transparency in linking public feedback to urban design solutions.
The application is a scalable, user-centric solution that addresses challenges in traditional
engagement methods, paving the way for more inclusive and impactful urban planning.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Project Overview

1.1 Company Introduction

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

The Urban Redevelopment Authority is the national land-use planning and conservation

authority in Singapore. Established to guide Singapore's physical development, URA is tasked
with formulating strategies that address the country's land constraints while ensuring sustainable
growth and liveability. Over the years, URA has played a pivotal role in shaping Singapore’s
transformation into a modern, vibrant, and highly liveable city-state. Its efforts are guided by a
long-term vision to balance economic development, environmental sustainability, and quality of
life. URA’s work spans various domains, including urban planning, heritage conservation,
infrastructure development, and placemaking initiatives.
URA’s approach to urban planning is underpinned by a data-driven and community-centered
philosophy. Through careful consideration of current and future trends, URA crafts development
strategies that address pressing challenges such as housing needs, mobility, and climate
resilience. By integrating innovative solutions into its planning processes, URA ensures that
Singapore remains adaptable to global changes while continuing to thrive as a competitive and
inclusive city.
1.2 Public Engagement Session
URA leverages the Master Plan as a statutory land-use blueprint to guide Singapore’s
development over the medium to long term, typically spanning 10 to 15 years. The Master Plan’s
primary objective is to optimize limited land resources, supporting sustainable growth while
enhancing the living environment for residents. Reviewed every five years, this dynamic plan
translates long-term strategies into actionable, detailed development plans.
Public engagement is an integral part of URA’s planning process. Through these sessions, URA
gathers insights, feedback, and aspirations from the community to ensure that urban development
aligns with the needs and desires of residents, businesses, and other stakeholders. These sessions
act as a bridge between planners and the public, fostering dialogue and mutual understanding.
Public engagement sessions not only provide a platform for participants to voice concerns and
share ideas but also encourage collaboration in the design of urban spaces. By involving diverse
community groups, URA ensures inclusivity, amplifying under-represented voices in the
planning process. This participatory approach cultivates a sense of ownership and belonging
among residents, strengthening their connection to their living spaces.
The insights and feedback collected during these sessions play a crucial role in shaping URA’s
policies and projects. They help ensure that the Master Plan remains responsive to the evolving

metadata.title: None Report - The Urban Redevelopment Authority is the national land-use planning and conservation
metadata.section_name: The Urban Redevelopment Authority is the national land-use planning and conservation

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

needs of Singapore’s population, maintaining its relevance and effectiveness in supporting
sustainable urban development.
1.3 Proposed Plan
To further URA’s mission of creating livable spaces, this project aims to enhance public
engagement through innovative approaches. By introducing interactive platforms and leveraging
advanced technologies, the project seeks to facilitate more meaningful and participatory
feedback processes. These insights will be systematically translated into actionable outcomes to
inform tangible spatial interventions within urban spaces. Serving as a bridge between URA’s
vision and the voices of the public, this project reinforces a collaborative and inclusive approach
to urban development.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

Research
2.1 Interview with URA
An interview session was conducted with representatives from the URA to gain deeper insights
into their current engagement methods and the challenges they face. Several critical insights
gathered from the discussion, offering a comprehensive understanding of their approaches and
areas for improvement.
Types of Engagement Sessions
URA adopts both conventional and AI-enhanced approaches to gather public feedback.
Conventional engagement methods include workshops and in-person discussions, while the more
recent integration of generative AI tools has allowed for the visualization of ideas through image
generation. This dual approach reflects URA’s commitment to embracing innovative
technologies alongside traditional practices to achieve more effective public participation.
Preparation of Engagement Sessions
The preparation process for engagement sessions is tailored to the specific site or scenario being
addressed. Project teams design public engagement frameworks and craft questions that align
with the objectives of each session. This targeted approach ensures that the feedback collected is
relevant and actionable, providing meaningful insights for urban planning decisions.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Translating Public Opinions into Actionable Outcomes

Key takeaways from public feedback are summarized to address participants' concerns.
However, no immediate commitments are made during the sessions. Instead, the feedback
undergoes further study and evaluation to ensure that decisions are inclusive, well-informed and
reflective of the broader community’s needs.

metadata.title: None Report - Translating Public Opinions into Actionable Outcomes
metadata.section_name: Translating Public Opinions into Actionable Outcomes

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Public Perception of AI Implementations

The perception of AI implementations among the public varies across demographic groups.
Younger participants adapt quickly to AI-based tools, demonstrating a high level of comfort and
engagement. Meanwhile, older generations feel empowered by being included in the process,
though some require additional assistance to effectively participate. This highlights the need for
accessible and inclusive tools to cater to all age groups.

metadata.title: None Report - Public Perception of AI Implementations

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

User Profiles in Decision-Making

User profiles also play a significant role in decision-making processes. Individuals who live in
the area of the engagement site or are part of groups directly related to the topic are given greater
priority in the feedback evaluation. These stakeholders are considered key contributors due to
their vested interest in the project outcomes, ensuring that their input carries substantial weight in
shaping decisions.

metadata.title: None Report - User Profiles in Decision-Making

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

2.2 Conventional Approach
Figure 1: Conventional Engagement Process Approach

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) traditionally adapts a manual, pen-and-paper-based

process. Figure 1 illustrates the workflow, starting from the use of sticky notes for ideation and
sharing, to curating a public exhibition of the outcome of the workshop. At the start of the
workshop, participants are strategically grouped, taking into account factors such as
demographics, backgrounds, and familiarity with the site. This approach ensures the formation of
well-balanced groups for effective results.

metadata.title: None Report - The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) traditionally adapts a manual, pen-and-paper-based
metadata.section_name: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) traditionally adapts a manual, pen-and-paper-based

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Sticky Note + Share

Within their groups, participants are encouraged to brainstorm and propose ideas for improving
the given site. They are free to explore any topics and write down as many ideas as possible on
sticky notes. Following this, each participant takes turns sharing their ideas with the group.
Group + Select
Subsequently, the group organises similar ideas into clusters and collaboratively selects the best
ideas to represent their collective vision.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Sketch Proposals

Participants are then tasked with visualising their group’s ideas through sketches. Pen and paper
are provided, and time is allocated for them to create their drawings.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Cross Share

Afterward, participants engage in a cross-sharing session, where they present their sketches and
ideas to members of other groups, fostering collaborative exchange and diverse perspectives.
Summarise
The workshop facilitators will collect all the sketches and sticky notes from the workshop and
summarise the results, consolidating the insights and ideas generated.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

Develop + Exhibit
Lastly, they will utilise the summarised results to develop an exhibition that showcases the
workshop’s outcome. This involves curating the collected sketches and ideas into a cohesive
narrative, creating visual displays that highlight key themes. The exhibition serves to engage
stakeholders, gather further feedback, and demonstrate the potential for future site improvements
based on the participants contribution.
2.3 URA AI Engagement Framework
Figure 2: AI Hybrid Engagement Process Approach
Alongside the conventional approach, URA has also embraced a more digitalised AI engagement
framework in response to the rise of AI tools. They leverage existing technologies, including
Chat GPT and Mid Journey, to enhance analytical insights and improve the visualization.
Question and Answer (Mentimeter)
URA designs site-specific questions to encourage meaningful engagement, combining
multiple-choice questions (MCQs) and open-ended queries. Predefined answers simplify the
response process, while open-ended questions allow participants to elaborate on their thoughts.
Mentimeter, an interactive tool, is used to collect real-time textual responses efficiently and
effectively.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

Participants use the questions as a starting point to brainstorm and share their ideas about what
they envision or prioritize. This collaborative process enables them to expand on their initial
thoughts and contribute creative and diverse perspectives via Mentimeter.
Upvote individual Ideas (Mentimeter)
Responses to open-ended questions are shared with the community, allowing participants to read
and evaluate others’ ideas. Through Mentimeter, they upvote the ideas they find most compelling
or relevant. This voting process ensures that the most popular and meaningful suggestions are
highlighted for deeper analysis, making the engagement more inclusive and community-driven.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Export Response Data (Excel)

The collected responses, along with their upvote counts, are exported to Excel format for further
processing.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Prompt Engineering (Chat GPT-4)

The exported data undergoes a two-stage prompt engineering process using Chat GPT-4, designed
to amplify community input and identify key themes for analysis:
First level: Replication Based on Upvote Weight
In the first stage, Chat GPT-4 processes the Excel data, which includes textual feedback and the
corresponding upvotes counts. Each response is duplicated in proportion to its upvote count,
ensuring that ideas with higher community support are given greater emphasis in the subsequent
analysis. This weighting mechanism ensures that the most popular and relevant ideas are not
diluted or overlooked during theme extraction and prompt generation.
Second level: Topic Modeling with LDA
Following replication, the enhanced dataset undergoes a topic modeling process using Latent
DIrichlet Allocation (LDA). This step identifies key themes or clusters from the feedback,
capturing the broad areas of concern or interest expressed by the participants. LDA ensures that
the extracted themes are distinct, non-overlapping, and reflective of diverse aspects of the
community’s input.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Generate Image Prompts (Chat GPT-4)

Based on the identified themes, Chat GPT-4 formulates distinct and detailed prompts for image
generation. These prompts incorporate critical keywords and elements derived from the
feedback, ensuring that the generated images align closely with the participants’ input and reflect
their original intentions.

metadata.title: None Report - Generate Image Prompts (Chat GPT-4)

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

The finalized prompts are processed using Mid Journey, an AI-based tool that creates visual
representations of the ideas. These images provide a tangible and immersive way to visualize
public feedback, making the engagement process more interactive and impactful.
2.4 Problem Scoping
Effective public engagement is a critical component of urban planning, as it ensures that
community needs and aspirations are integrated into the design and development process.
However, both conventional and AI-driven engagement approaches face challenges that need to
be addressed for more impactful outcomes. The three identified issues in the engagement process
are as follows:

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Manual Toggling Between Applications

The current AI approach is innovative, but it suffers from inefficiencies caused by the manual
toggling between multiple applications at different stages of the workflow. For instance, public
feedback collected through Mentimeter is exported to Excel for data organization, then processed
through Chat GPT-4 for prompt engineering, and finally input into Mid Journey for visualization.
This fragmented process not only consumes time but also increases the likelihood of errors,
creating a barrier to seamless integration of AI technologies into the engagement framework.

metadata.title: None Report - Manual Toggling Between Applications

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Disconnection Between Public Feedback and Urban Design

In both conventional and AI approaches, there exists a gap between the insights gathered from
public feedback and their translation into actionable urban design solutions. While feedback is
collected and categorized effectively, the connection between these insights and the resulting
urban development plans often remains unclear. This disconnection can lead to public
disengagement, as stakeholders may feel that their contributions are not directly influencing
planning outcomes. Addressing this issue requires mechanisms to bridge the gap between
participatory input and urban design implementation.
Difficulty in Translating Public Input into Actionable Outcomes
Both conventional and AI engagement methods face challenges in transforming diverse and
often unstructured public input into clear, actionable outcomes. The complexity of integrating
qualitative data, such as community preferences and concerns, into measurable urban planning
objectives makes the process inherently difficult. This challenge is exacerbated when public
input is abstract, subjective, or fragmented, necessitating advanced tools and methodologies to
synthesize these ideas into actionable designs and strategies.
2.5 Problem Statement
The identified challenges - manual toggling between applications, the disconnection between
public feedback and urban design, and the difficulty in translating public input into actionable

metadata.title: None Report - Disconnection Between Public Feedback and Urban Design
metadata.section_name: Disconnection Between Public Feedback and Urban Design

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

outcomes - highlight inefficiencies and gaps in the current engagement processes. These issues
hinder the ability to fully integrate community input into urban planning strategies.
Building on these challenges, the problem can be framed as follows:
“How might we integrate Artificial Intelligence (AI) to enhance user engagement, enabling
users to express desired space changes and distill actionable outcomes from their feedback?”
2.6 Proposed Approach
Building on the problem statement and URA's existing engagement framework, the proposed
approach seeks to revolutionize public engagement in urban planning by leveraging AI
technologies and an inclusive, user-centric solution. The goal is to empower users to contribute
meaningfully while streamlining the workflow for administrators, fostering a deeper connection
between public feedback and actionable outcomes.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

1. Empowering Public Engagement

The solution will enable users to visually express desired space changes, helping them
see how their input directly influences urban design. This fosters transparency and builds
a stronger connection between public feedback and decision-making processes.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

2. Leveraging AI for Actionable Outcomes

By using AI, the system will transform public feedback into real-time visualizations of
urban space changes. This approach will help translate user input into actionable design
proposals, while also tracking user preferences and identifying emerging trends to inform
inclusive and sustainable decisions.

Database UML Diagram
Figure 3: Database UML Diagram
The application was built mainly on four types of resources: engagements, questionnaires,
generations, and users. This structure was chosen to ensure that the system is as customizable
and dynamic as it can be. Here is the breakdown for each resource:

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

1. Engagements: Represents the engagement / event that URA holds.

○ image Url: Saved url of the engagement’s main image (the image users will be
able to edit with)
○ image Caption: Context given to the main image such that context can be passed
to the backend APIs for better generation results.
○ location: Google maps link of the location of engagement
○ title: Title or name of the engagement

questionnaire links up to the specific engagement in the database by being nested in this

○ questions: All the questions within that questionnaire; where each question entity

3.2 Admin Interface (Create)
Figure 4: User Workflow of Admin Interface (Create)
The admin dashboard has two workflows: the first being the process of creating the engagement
that users will interact with.
The process starts with the admin inputting the title of the engagement as well as the Google
Maps link of the location. Then they proceed to upload the image that will be shown to all users
during the image generation section. This is accompanied by a context description which they
have to input as well. Lastly, the admin has to create the questionnaire in regards to that specific
engagement that will be shown after the user signs up to the application. The questionnaire can
include questions that are free-response type, or multi-select.

The admin begins on a landing page displaying an overview of all ongoing engagement

different engagement sessions at a glance, to avoid repetition of engagement sessions that
they have already created in the past. This is to also ensure quick access to any of the

Upon clicking the “Create New Engagement Session” button, the admin is prompted to

this such that users will all be evaluating the exact same coordinates for a fair
engagement, otherwise different users may evaluate different parts of the assigned

The admin can then upload images of the actual site, which will serve as the base for

be helpful, especially to participants who haven’t visited the site before. This is to also
help inform the AI model in the backend about more context on the image its processing.

Content

3.3 User Interface
Figure 5: User Workflow of User Interface
The user interface has a straight-forward workflow. The team wanted to ensure that the user
didn’t have to toggle between a lot of screens, and just allow for a smooth linear progression
from the start of the application to the end.
The user starts with being welcomed and introduced to the application, then proceeds to fill in
their particulars, the questionnaire, and finally meet the characters that will provide feedback on
their generation. The bulk of the workflow happens during the image workshop.
The image workshop has two tabs: one that allows the user to in-paint, and the other to input the
prompt. If the user decides to click on the tools and in-paint, they are still required to input a
prompt. The system will detect that the in-painting option has been picked, and it will send the
request to our backend with models realistic-vision-v5-1-inpainting, and GPT 4 o-mini.
Implementation and information on all the models mentioned in the workflows will be detailed
later in the report at Section 3.5. Essentially, the second model will upscale the prompt that the

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

user inputs, to make it more descriptive. Then this upscaled prompt will be passed in the first
model, alongside the in-painted image. The model returns back the generated image which will
then be critiqued by the same GPT 4 o-mini in which we have prompted with the different
characters.
If the system has not detected any tools being used, that means that no in-painting has been done.
If this is the case, the model we are passing the image to is realvis-xl-v4. This serves as an
image-to-image generation. The prompt is still upscaled before that by GPT 4 o-mini, and the
same critique workflow applies after.
Once the image generation has been completed, the user can repeat the entire workflow again to
generate another image, and so on. When they are satisfied with the final generated image, they
can then end their journey.
After the end of the image workshop session, users will be directed to an image feed that they
can scroll through to view all other generations by other participants, as well as view each post
individually.
The next section will detail each of the processes described in this overview, as well as showcase
the user interfaces that are displayed in each step.
Interface
For the interface, the goal here is to create a platform that is effective and intuitive to all user
profiles -- ranging from young students to older folks that may not be as exposed to technology.
The following are the various screens that the user will be exposed to:

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

1. User Welcome

The user will be first welcomed with a series of screens that introduces them to what the
application is about. On the last of the screens, the user will be able to click a ‘View Location in
Maps’ button that will lead them to a direct link of the Google Map coordinates of the site. This
is such that the user can explore the area in a 3 D street view, and understand the context of the
location they’re engaging about.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

2. User Particulars

The user will be led to a screen where they can input their essential information. The reason why
the team decided to collect postal codes is for the possibility that URA may want to start
weighing the opinions of the users based on who actually lives in the area or not.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

3. Questionnaire

The questionnaire is a series of questions curated by the admin, that collects the user preference
data. This is to allow the admin to find out more about the user’s thoughts on the location and
why they may generate certain topics. The choices presented are displayed in the form of large
buttons, as the target users may have shaky hands (especially older folks), which will give them
difficulty pressing smaller radio-buttons.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

4. Meet the Characters

This screen introduces the various characters that will be critiquing the user’s image generation
later on. The purpose of this is to inform the user on the various considerations that they may
miss out on whilst generating their image; considerations include topics such as accessibility,
safety, play, sustainability, and more. The team has decided to attach generated cartoon images
for each character, to give personality and allow the users to feel more connected to them.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

5. Image Workshop and Character Feedback

This is the main section where all user image generations happen in the application. Here, the
user is greeted with a prompt input that they can fill in. Clicking the sparkle icon at the right
corner of the input section will then generate the image based on the prompt. If no inpainting has
been done, then the system will call the image to image function to generate the image.
Otherwise, if the user decides to use the tools and start inpainting on the image, the system will
call the inpainting function, in order to apply the prompt input only in that specific area. For the

metadata.title: None Report - 5. Image Workshop and Character Feedback

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

inpainting option, brush size can be adjusted to better suit the user’s needs. Users are able to
download the image as well in order to save all their iterations.
All prompts in the input section will be upscaled in the backend, as users may input vague
descriptions that will cause the image generation to not produce accurate results. The team aimed
to relieve the user from using too much cognitive load in curating the perfect prompt, and allow
them to instead prompt anything that they want and let their creativity flow.
Once the image is generated, a scrollable feedback modal will pop up. The user is required to
scroll and read through everything before clicking the ‘Acknowledge’ button that will close the
modal. This is to encourage users to be more aware of the various issues that they need to
consider when generating such images.
When the modal closes, the user can then scroll through all the iterations that they have created
via the image carousel buttons.
The session will be completed once the button ‘End Journey’ is pressed. This button is separated
from the generation button, as users are able to keep on generating new images or end their
session. This design choice was not the best, as the users during the actual engagement had
difficulty distinguishing between the two buttons, and would accidentally click end journey --
thinking they’re able to generate more images.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

6. Generation Feed

Users are able to scroll through and view the various generations viewed by the other
participants in the engagement session. This is to foster community interaction and provide
insight on what others in the community are thinking about.
Users can also like the posts that they enjoy via clicking the heart icon on the top right. The
ability to like generations are informative for the URA admins to know which designs do the
majority of the participants agree / resonate with.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

7. Individual Generation Post

The last screen that users can see is the individual post details. This page can be reached by
clicking a post from the feed. The information showcased includes the image generated, the user
handle, the upscaled prompt, as well as a heart icon that the user can click to like the post.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

3.4 Admin Interface (View & Analyze Data)
Figure 6: User Workflow of Admin Interface (View & Analyze Data)
As mentioned earlier in Section 3.2 in the document, the admin dashboard has two workflows.
The second one is meant for the admin to view all the analytics and responses of the engagement.
After the engagement session has been conducted, the admin can then view three types of data.
First, the home analytics section showcases a range of user data in a summarized manner. It
displays the participants list, regions of where the users come from, user profiles, and more
condensed information that can come in useful for them. For instance, the heatmap provides the
parts of the image where the users have in-painted the most, indicating the areas the public most

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

wanted changing. There is also a community image that can be generated here, which is
showcased to the participants to allow them to see their creations as part of the bigger picture.
The model gpt-4 o-mini processes all the saved upscaled prompts of the users during the
generations, and combines them to form one descriptive prompt inclusive of all the ideas. This
prompt is passed in realvis-xl-v4, which generates the image. A word cloud of the most popular
words are displayed in this section as well.
Second, the questionnaire section showcases a summary of all the question responses of the
participants. Bar graphs display the multi-select answers, but the free responses have their own
section. Free responses are further categorized, as vague questions will elicit responses that span
across multiple topics. The team uses the models BERTopic and gpt-4 o-mini to break down
responses to its respective domains.
Lastly, the image generations section displays all generations created by the participants of that
engagement. Admins can further analyze a generation by viewing its individual details alongside
the profile of the user who generated that image.
Interface

Document: Final Technical Report

Admin is able to analyse the most popular answer as well as the number of votes

for each answer with ease.

3.5 Artificial Intelligence Models
As mentioned in the various parts of the interface walkthroughs, a crucial part of allowing the
team’s vision to come to life was with the use of AI models. This section will be broken down
into the various models used throughout the project.
All these models are running via a backend Flask application in the main codebase. These
endpoints are being called in the frontend to connect it with the interface. The structure of which
these responses are returned, are all determined based on what is the most convenient way to
map out the data in conjunction with React Java Script.
Inpainting (Editing of Image)
One of the crucial sections of our application was the inpainting. To achieve this, we tried
different pipelines and methodologies.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

1. Hugging Face Diffusers: Auto Pipeline for Inpainting

We initially were ambitious and used Hugging Face’s Auto Pipeline For Inpainting, a part of the
Diffusers library. This pipeline is designed to perform inpainting tasks by taking an input image,
a mask image, and a textual prompt describing the modifications.

metadata.title: None Report - 1. Hugging Face Diffusers: Auto Pipeline for Inpainting
metadata.section_name: 1. Hugging Face Diffusers: Auto Pipeline for Inpainting

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

We tested several models with this pipeline, including Stability AI Stable Diffusion 2
Inpainting (stabilityai/stable-diffusion-2-inpainting), Runway ML Stable Diffusion v1-5
(runwayml/stable-diffusion-v1-5), and Diffusers Stable Diffusion XL Inpainting 1.0
(diffusers/stable-diffusion-xl-1.0-inpainting-0.1).
This pipeline processes these inputs and generates a modified image that blends the masked
regions with the rest of the content. However, this method required a powerful GPU for efficient
processing. Even with an NVIDIA RTX 3090, the process took over 35 seconds for a single
image. This was a crucial metric when choosing the right inpainting pipeline as it really takes the
users out of the engagement process.
While the outputs of the stable-diffusion-2 and stable-diffusion-xl-1.0-inpainting were highly
realistic, the computational cost made this approach unsuitable for large-scale or user-facing
applications.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

2. Open AI DALL·E 2

After encountering the limitations with the Hugging Face Diffusers, we decided to test Open AI’s
DALL.E 2. As of recently DALL.E 2 allows for inpainting or outpainting an image by specifying
a mask and a text prompt. This approach promised a more accessible API and simplified the
computational requirements, making it a suitable candidate for scalable and user-friendly
applications.
To implement inpainting using DALL·E 2, we leveraged Open AI's Python API. The process
involved uploading a square Portable Network Graphics (PNG) image as the base, and an alpha
channel mask to indicate the areas for modification (transparent regions signifying the editable
parts). Along with these inputs, a descriptive text prompt detailing the desired edits was
provided. The API processed the inputs and returned a URL to the edited image.
However, the quality of DALL.E 2’s outputs was not as expected. For simple scenes, it produced
acceptable results, but for complex scenes, it often failed to deliver with most generations turning
blanks or with random artifacts.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

3. Realistic Vision v5.1 (Getimg.ai)

Getimg.ai stood out for its competitive pricing, with inpainting generations costing as little as
$0.00075 per image, making it highly cost-effective for large-scale applications. Its lightning-fast
performance ensured near-instant results, even for high-resolution images. Furthermore, the
platform provided access to a wide array of models tailored to different tasks, such as inpainting,

Project Report: None Document: Final Technical Report Content text-to-image, and image-to-image transformations. This versatility allowed us to experiment with multiple models and choose the one that best suited our requirements. To integrate Getimg.ai into our workflow, we used its inpainting API via Python. The Realistic Vision v5.1 (from the stable-diffusion/inpaint family) Inpainting model was selected due to its ability to maintain consistency in complex scenes and its efficient processing capabilities, aligning with our requirements for scalability and quality. The process involved resizing the input image and mask to a uniform size (512 x512), encoding them into base64 format, and sending them to the API along with a descriptive text prompt. The API processed these inputs and returned a URL to the edited image, which was simply used as the source for the tag in the frontend. The API’s adjustable parameters, such as strength, guidance, and steps, allowed us to refine the outputs further, ensuring a balance between realism and prompt adherence. Image to Image As we progressed with the project, user feedback revealed a clear trend: most users wanted a straightforward method to transform their images without manually drawing over the images. While the inpainting feature offered some precise control, it often felt cumbersome to those who simply wanted an overarching transformation of their entire image based on a textual prompt.

Project Report: None Document: Final Technical Report With Getimg.ai integrated into our workflow, we had access to a wide range of stable diffusion models optimized for different styles and applications. After experimenting with multiple models, we settled on realvis-xl-v4 from the stable-diffusion-xl family. Its robustness in handling diverse prompts made it the ideal choice for the img2 img feature. The img2 img process begins with the user-uploaded image which is resized to 512 x512 pixels. This resizing is model specific. The resized image is then encoded into a base64 format and is sent to the API along with a detailed textual prompt describing the desired transformation. The payload sent to the Getimg.ai API includes the base64-encoded image, the user’s prompt, and the configured parameters. Once complete, the API returns a URL pointing to the transformed image. The URL returned, was simply used as the source for the tag in the frontend. The returned URL is preloaded to ensure the image is fully ready for display without delays.

metadata.title: None Report - With Getimg.ai integrated into our workflow, we had access to a wide range of stable diffusion
metadata.section_name: With Getimg.ai integrated into our workflow, we had access to a wide range of stable diffusion

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Character Impact Analysis

The core idea was to leverage LLM agents to simulate human personas and provide actionable
feedback tailored to specific user groups. By modeling diverse human needs, the system ensures

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

that users receive insights during each iteration of their design process. This feedback helps users
understand how their designs align with or deviate from the expectations of different
demographic groups and guides them toward creating more inclusive and impactful solutions.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Character Focus

Mrs. Eleanor Tan Accessibility, healthcare, safety
Kumar and Priya Family amenities, education, safety

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Ethan Lim Study areas, affordability

Table 2 Characters and Respective Focuses
The core mechanism involves crafting structured prompts that guide Open AI's GPT-4 o API,
which supports vision inputs, to generate concise and actionable feedback in JSON format.
These prompts clearly describe the persona's traits and needs, enabling the API to focus on
generating relevant insights.
The inputs sent to the API include the image URL, which serves as the visual context for
analysis, and a detailed prompt specifying the personas and their requirements. Initially, we
considered using models like (Bootstrapped Language-Image Pretraining) BLIP or (Contrastive
Language–Image Pretraining) CLIP to caption the image generations and use those captions to
inform the analysis. However, since the image generation step already precedes this section,
introducing additional latency further disrupts the user experience, causing delays that could
make the app feel unresponsive and deter users from engaging with it effectively. Hence, we
proceeded with using GPT-4 o.

metadata.title: None Report - Ethan Lim Study areas, affordability

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Prompt Upscaling

During testing, we noticed that many users, especially elderly individuals, had trouble writing
good prompts for editing or generating images. They were unfamiliar with how to structure AI
prompts and found it hard to describe their ideas clearly. To help, we added a feature that
automatically improves their prompts. This makes the app easier to use and reduces the effort
required to create detailed instructions.
When a user submits a prompt, they also specify the mode—either img2 img for broad
transformations or inpainting for targeted edits. The backend processes the prompt using a
function called improve_caption, which sends the user’s input, along with the selected mode, to

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

GPT-4 o-mini. We have crafted unique prompts for each mode, tailored to the specific
requirements of img2 img and inpainting tasks.
The refined prompt, designed to be clearer, more detailed, and actionable, is then sent to the
image generation process along with the input image and/or a mask image, ensuring precise and
high-quality outputs that align with the user’s intent.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Word Generations

For the section on topic modelling on free response questions and as well as word cloud
generation, we explored multiple methodologies. Referencing the provided tables, we compared
Open AI GPT, BERTopic, Topic GPT, and Custom Prompt Topic. To evaluate these
methodologies, we established runtime performance and coherence value as our primary metrics.
After conducting a detailed comparison, we found that the performance between Open AI GPT
and BERTopic was close. However, BERTopic demonstrated greater consistency when working
with larger text corpora, making it the final choice for our implementation.

Table 3 Comparison of Models for Word Generation
The `initialize_basic_topic_model` function and the `generate_words` endpoint work together
to enable topic modeling and word extraction using BERTopic. The
`initialize_basic_topic_model` function sets up the BERTopic model to capture clusters while
filtering out noise. A minimum topic size of 3 ensures that only clusters with at least three
samples are considered, avoiding smaller, insignificant groups. The model's configuration
includes an n-gram range of (1, 2), which captures both single words and short phrases for better
contextual insights.
The input prompts are processed using the `fit_transform` method, which identifies clusters or
topics within the data. For each topic, the top words and their weights are extracted, and a
dictionary aggregates the cumulative frequencies of these words across all topics. The words are
then sorted in descending order of importance based on their weights, creating a ranked list of
terms most relevant to the identified topics. This list is returned as a JSON response back to

metadata.title: None Report - Criteria Open AI GPT BERTopic Topic GPT
metadata.section_name: Criteria Open AI GPT BERTopic Topic GPT

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Topic Generation

The generate-topics endpoint builds upon the same methodology used in word extraction but
leverages an additional feature of BERTopic: the representation model. This feature allows for
refining the raw word clusters into meaningful, high-level topics. While the clustering process
remains similar—identifying clusters within the input data using embeddings, dimensionality
reduction, and density-based clustering—the representation model steps in to label these clusters
with coherent, human-readable topics rather than just raw words. The endpoint ultimately returns
up to 20 of these topics in a JSON response, ensuring that they are both meaningful and easy to
interpret.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

The Community Image endpoint is the culmination of all the methodologies we have developed

so far, combining the BERTopic for meaningful representation and GPT-4 o for prompt
generation, ultimately feeding into the img2 img (Getimg.ai) API for visual output. The goal was
to create a community image that combines all contributions and showcase it back to the
participants, helping them see how their ideas come together into a shared vision.

metadata.title: None Report - The Community Image endpoint is the culmination of all the methodologies we have developed
metadata.section_name: The Community Image endpoint is the culmination of all the methodologies we have developed

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

The way it is done is by accepting a set of user-provided prompts, which are processed to extract
the most significant words using the generate_words method. Using BERTopic, this step
identifies clusters and aggregates the most important terms, effectively distilling the key
elements from the input data. These words are then concatenated into a coherent string to form
the basis for further processing.
Next, the extracted words are passed to GPT-4 o to generate a concise and context-aware Stable
Diffusion prompt.
Once the prompt is ready, the endpoint prepares the user-provided image (if any) by resizing it to
fit the required dimensions (maintaining an aspect ratio with a maximum size of 1024 x1024).
The image, along with the refined prompt, is sent to the img2 img API for processing. This final
step uses the realvis-xl-v4 model to transform the image based on the refined prompt, producing
a visual output that embodies the themes and ideas extracted earlier.
With that, the application has been fully built and it was time to test it with an actual engagement
session.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Engagement Session and Results

4.1 Choosing the Site for Engagement
The site was recommended by the URA as part of the ongoing Drafted Master Plan 2025 public
engagement efforts. URA had previously engaged residents and stakeholders to explore ideas for
transforming the sheltered viaduct space below the Queensway Flyover into a new community
node.
Following confirmation of the site, a site visit was conducted to analyze the area and its
surroundings. This included observing existing features, assessing accessibility, and
understanding the current use of space to inform the application testing process.
The location is part of the Alexandra-Queensway Park Connector, which serves as a vital link
connecting nearby HDB estates to the Rail Corridor. The space is situated beneath a highway,
functions as an underpass that facilitates accessibility and encourages active mobility, offering a
seamless connection in the direction towards Tanjong Pagar and Woodlands.
4.2 Choosing of Participants for the Engagement
To ensure a diverse and representative group, participants were selected across various
demographics, including age, gender, and background. The group ranged from university
students to elderly residents, providing valuable insights into the differing needs, perspectives,
and expectations of users across generations. This approach ensured that the feedback collected
was inclusive and reflective of the broader community's interests.
4.3 Hosting of the Engagement
The application was tested during an in-person session with eight people, held at the URA
building. Due to timetable clashes within the participants, the team was not able to hold this
event in the actual engagement site.
In-Person Session
The application testing was conducted through an in-person session involving a total of eight
participants. This number was chosen to ensure a manageable and focused group size, allowing
for thorough observation and data collection.

metadata.title: None Report - Engagement Session and Results

content:
Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Session Structure

The session was structured to compare the traditional method of using the application with our
newly developed method. To achieve this, the participants were randomly divided into two
groups of equal sizes. This division enabled a controlled comparison between the two methods,

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Content

ensuring that any differences observed could be attributed to the methods themselves rather than
other variables.

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Methodology

Each group was initially exposed to one of the two methods. One group started with the
traditional method, while the other group began with our new method. This initial exposure
allowed participants to familiarize themselves with the respective methods and complete a set of
tasks or interactions as required by the application.
After the initial exposure, the groups were swapped. This meant that the group that initially used
the traditional method then switched to our new method, and vice versa. This swap was crucial
as it ensured that each participant had the opportunity to experience both methods, thereby
reducing any bias that might be associated with individual preferences or the order of exposure.
4.4 Data Collection
To gather comprehensive feedback and assess the user experience, exit surveys were conducted
at the end of each method's trial. To ensure consistency in data collection, the same set of survey
questions was used across both methods.
The survey was designed to collect both quantitative and qualitative data using a mix of
multiple-choice questions (MCQ), rating scales, and open-ended responses. This approach
enabled a thorough evaluation of user satisfaction, workflow usability, and areas for
improvement, providing a well-rounded understanding of participants’ experiences.
The exit survey began by recording participants' names and the method they were allocated to.
This ensured that feedback could be analyzed at both group and individual levels, facilitating
targeted observations and comparisons.
The key survey questions were grouped into the following categories, each serving a specific
purpose:

Project Report: None
Document: Final Technical Report

Overall Experience and Usability

● How satisfied were you with the overall experience of using the workflow? (Rating)
Reason: To measure participants’ overall satisfaction and the effectiveness of the
workflow in providing a positive user experience.
● Was the workflow intuitive and easy to follow? (Rating)
Reason: To assess the usability and clarity of the workflow, ensuring it is easy to
navigate.
Strengths and Areas of Flexibility

● What did you like the most about the workflow?
Reason: To identify the key strengths and positive aspects that stood out to participants.
● Did the workflow give you enough flexibility to edit or adjust the image? (MCQ)
Reason: To evaluate the degree of control users had in modifying the generated output.
Quality and Alignment of Output
● Did the generated image align with your expectations and prompt input? (MCQ)
Reason: To determine how accurately the workflow delivered results based on user input.
● Rate the quality of the final image you generated. (Rating)
Reason: To measure the perceived quality of the generated images, which is critical for
assessing workflow success.
Engagement and Motivation
● Did you feel engaged and motivated throughout the process? (Rating)
Reason: To assess the level of user engagement, which is vital for a positive and
productive experience.
Challenges and Usability Issues
● Did you encounter any difficulties throughout the process? (MCQ)
Reason: To identify any usability issues or obstacles faced during the workflow.
● If yes, how many times did you need to retry or adjust the steps? (MCQ)
Reason: To quantify the frequency of challenges, providing insights into workflow
stability and ease of use.
● If yes, please describe the challenges you faced and how they affected your experience.
Reason: To gather qualitative data on the nature of the challenges and their impact on the
overall experience.

Future Adoption and Improvement

● How likely are you to use this workflow again for similar tasks? (Rating)
Reason: To gauge the potential for continued use and measure the workflow’s value for
future tasks or sessions.
● What improvements or additional features would you like to see in the workflow?
Reason: To gather suggestions for enhancements and identify areas for further
development.

Additional Feedback

● Do you have any other feedback about the workflows or your experience?
Reason: To provide participants with an open-ended opportunity to share additional
thoughts or observations not covered in previous questions.

Project Report: None

Content

This structured survey design ensures that all critical aspects of the workflow—including
usability, user satisfaction, challenges, and future adoption—are addressed. The collected data
provides a clear, actionable foundation for analyzing user experiences and identifying areas for
improvement. Results from the survey will be analyzed in the following section.
4.5 Results Analysis
The survey results from both trials were compared to identify any significant differences in user
experience, satisfaction, and performance between the two methods. This comparison was
essential in evaluating the efficacy and user acceptance of our new method relative to the
traditional method.
By analysing the feedback and responses from both surveys, we were able to determine whether
our new method offered any improvements over the existing one. This analysis included
statistical comparisons, thematic analysis of qualitative feedback, and an overall assessment of
user preferences and experiences.
